facts.text: Datar Singh was convicted under Section 302 Indian Penal Code by the Sessions Judge of Patiala for murdering his father Thakar Singh

anchor.surface_text: Datar Singh, appellant, was companyvicted under Section. 302 Indian Penal Code by the Sessions Judge of Patiala for murdering his father Thakar Singh at about 9.30 p.m. on 22-2-1970 at Naru House in Patiala, and sentenced to death.

facts.text: Thakar Singh was murdered at about 9.30 p.m. on 22-2-1970 at Naru House in Patiala

anchor.surface_text: Datar Singh, appellant, was companyvicted under Section. 302 Indian Penal Code by the Sessions Judge of Patiala for murdering his father Thakar Singh at about 9.30 p.m. on 22-2-1970 at Naru House in Patiala, and sentenced to death.

facts.text: Datar Singh was sentenced to death by Sessions Judge of Patiala

anchor.surface_text: , and sentenced to death. The Punjab High Court had accepted the death reference and dismissed his appeal.

facts.text: Punjab High Court accepted the death reference and dismissed Datar Singh's appeal

anchor.surface_text: The Punjab High Court had accepted the death reference and dismissed his appeal. He was also companyvicted in a companynected trial, for an alleged illegal possession of a gun,

facts.text: Datar Singh convicted for illegal possession of a gun under Sections 25 and 27 of Arms Act, sentences of two years and three years RI upheld by High Court

anchor.surface_text: He was also companyvicted in a companynected trial, for an alleged illegal possession of a gun, and his companyvictions and sentences of two years rigorous imprisonment and three years rigorous imprisonment under Sections 25 p and 27 of Arms Act were upheld by the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal in both connected cases

anchor.surface_text: The appellants applications under Article 134 1   c  under the Constitution having been rejected by the High Court, he came to this Court and was granted special leave to appeal in both the companynected cases which are number before us.

facts.text: Thakar Singh executed a will in favour of his wife and two sons Avtar Singh and Datar Singh on 24-8-1967

anchor.surface_text: Thakar Singh, deceased was a wealthy landlord whose sister was the Maharani of Patiala. He had executed a will in favour of his wife and two sons Avtar Singh, and Datar Singh on 24-8-1967.

facts.text: Thakar Singh cancelled the 1967 will and executed another in favour of his sister Rani Prem Kaur on 18-4-1968 registered at Dhuri

anchor.surface_text: He cancelled this will and executed another in-favour of his sister Rani Prem Kaur on 18-4-1968 and got it registered at Dhuri probably because Joginder Singh, W.1., a friend of his, was the Sub Registrar there.

facts.text: Thakar Singh alienated some property in favour of Jasvinder Singh, minor son of Joginder Singh, about a year and a half before the murder

anchor.surface_text: The deceased Thakar Singh had also alienated some property in favour of Jasvinder Singh, minor, aged about 10 or 11 years, a son of Joginder Singh, P.W.1, about a year and a half before the murder.

facts.text: Avtar Singh filed a suit to preempt the sale to Jasvinder Singh, suit pending at time of occurrence

anchor.surface_text: Avtar Singh, the elder son of Thakar Singh, had filed a suit to preempt this sale. The suit was pending at the time of the occurrence.

facts.text: Relations of Thakar Singh with his wife and children were strained

anchor.surface_text: The relations of Thakar Singh deceased with his wife and children were strained. This background was said to provide the motive for murder.

facts.text: Joginder Singh PW1 left Sunam at 2.45 or 3 p.m. on 22-2-1970, reached Patiala by 4 or 5 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: He stated in cross-examination that he had left Sunam, where he was posted as Naib Tehsildar, at 2.45 or3 p.m., reaching Patiala by 4 or 5p.m.

facts.text: FIR lodged at Police Station Civil Lines Patiala on 22-2-1970 at 9.55 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: although his name is mentioned in the F.I.R. which was shown as lodged at Police Station, Civil Lines, Patiala, on 22-2- 1970, as early as 9.55 p.m.

facts.text: Balbir Singh PW2 wrote a letter dated 20-4-1970 stating he did not witness the murder

anchor.surface_text: yet, he had, we think, made an even more serious and damaging declaration in a letter dated 20-4-1970  Ex. X , He had stated there that he had number witnessed the murder at all and that the police was harassing him to make a false statement.

facts.text: Handwriting expert Shanti Sarup Jain DW1 opined that handwriting on Ex. X tallied with Balbir Singh's

anchor.surface_text: The relevant documents were, however, sent to and examined by Shanti Sarup Jain, D.W.1, a handwriting expert who had given a detailed report for companying to the companyclusion that the hand- writing on the letter  Ex. X  tallied with the admitted hand-writing of Balbir Singh, P.W.2.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds Joginder Singh PW1 and Balbir Singh PW2 unreliable eye-witnesses

anchor.surface_text: After having been taken through the evidence on record we have companye to the companyclusion that the superstructure of the prosecution. case is based on the testimony of two alleged eye-witnesses whose evidence is number only of an inherently unreliable nature but the artificial and incredible versions of the shooting put forward by them are too unnatural to be accepted.

facts.text: Postmortem by Dr. G.S. Gambhir showed injuries caused from about 6 feet distance

anchor.surface_text: Dr. G. S. Gambhir, the Medical Officer, who had performed the postmortem examination, said, after looking at, the injuries of Thakar Singh These injuries were caused when the numberzle of the gun was at a distance of about 6 feet from the body.

facts.text: Gun belonged to Mohan Singh, son-in-law of Thakar Singh

anchor.surface_text: The gun was proved, from its licence, to belong to Mohan Singh, the son-in-law of Thakar. Singh.

facts.text: Ballistic expert K. Sinha DW10 could not connect cartridges with the gun

anchor.surface_text: The ballistic expert, called in as a defence witness, was number even questioned on the point, Here, we may refer to the evidence of Ballistic expert Shri K. Sinha, D-W. 10. Assistant Director of the Forensic Science Laboratory, who was number produced by the prosecution probably because he had made a report showing that it was number possible to companynect the cartridges with the gun as the impressions made by the hammer were too indistinct.

facts.text: Supreme Court acquitted Datar Singh as prosecution case fails

anchor.surface_text: In any case the super-structure of the prosecution case, based on the testimony of two alleged eye witnesses, having crumbled in the case before us, we find it impossible number to give the appellant the benefit of doubt because of circumstances which companyld only raise suspicion against him.

facts.text: Pyarelal DW8 stated no chick hanging outside Chowbara door and no body seen in Chowbara after murder

anchor.surface_text: Peareylal  D.W. 8 , the domestic servant of Thakar Singh, who asserted that he was the first to companye to the Chowbara from the kitchen after the murder deposed that he saw numberody in the Chowbara where the dead body of Thakar Singh lay. He denied the presence of the two alleged eye-witnesses there. He stated, under cross-examination, that numberchick was hanging outside the door of the Chowbara.

facts.text: Datar Singh claimed alibi at Delhi Sarai Gurdwara Sis Ganj on 22-2-1970

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had given some evidence to support his plea that he was actually at Delhi staying at the Sarai of Gurdwara Sis Ganj on 22-2-1970.

facts.text: Appellant not traceable until surrender nearly a year after murder

anchor.surface_text: Considerable emphasis has been laid by learned Counsel for the State on the fact that the appellant was number traceable or was absconding until he surrendered in a Magistrates companyrt nearly a year after the murder.

facts.text: Site plan prepared by Bakshi Singh PW10 on 24-2-1970

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned here that tile site plan, relied upon by the High Court to give 7 feet as the distance between the door and the place on the sofa where Thakar Singh was sitting, was prepared by a Draftsman, Bakshi Singh, P.W. 10, on 24-2-1970,

facts.text: No fingerprints examined on the gun

anchor.surface_text: It was number sent for examination of any finger prints on it. Had there been such evidence of the appellants finger prints on the gun, it would have furnished strong companyroborative evidence.

holdings.text: The superstructure of the prosecution case is based on the testimony of two alleged eye-witnesses whose evidence is not only of an inherently unreliable nature but the artificial and incredible versions of the shooting put forward by them are too unnatural to be accepted.

anchor.surface_text: After having been taken through the evidence on record we have come to the conclusion that the superstructure of the prosecution case is based on the testimony of two alleged eye-witnesses whose evidence is not only of an inherently unreliable nature but the artificial and incredible versions of the shooting put forward by them are too unnatural to be accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contradictions in timing, presence, medical evidence mismatch, Ex. X letter authenticity, unnatural entry and shooting description, failure to pursue assailant.

holdings.text: It seems to us to be quite unsafe to convict the appellant on their testimony despite some circumstances which raise grave suspicion against the appellant. Suspicion, however grave, cannot be a satisfactory basis for convicting an accused person.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us to be quite unsafe to convict the appellant on their testimony despite some circumstances which raise grave suspicion against the appellant. Suspicion, however grave, cannot be a satisfactory basis for convicting an accused person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unreliable eyewitness testimony cannot support conviction even with suspicious circumstances; prosecution must prove beyond reasonable doubt.

holdings.text: We find it impossible not to give the appellant the benefit of doubt because of circumstances which could only raise suspicion against him.

anchor.surface_text: In any case the super-structure of the prosecution case, based on the testimony of two alleged eye witnesses, having crumbled in the case before us, we find it impossible not to give the appellant the benefit of doubt because of circumstances which could only raise suspicion against him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution superstructure crumbled due to unreliable witnesses; mere suspicion insufficient for conviction.

holdings.text: The case discloses exceptional features indicating a serious miscarriage of justice warranting disturbance of concurrent findings of fact.

anchor.surface_text: It has been contended on behalf of the appellant that such a miscarriage of justice has resulted in this case because Courts ignored certain basic defects in the prosecution version and misread evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Misreading of evidence (e.g., handwriting expert), ignored contradictions, basic defects in prosecution version lead to miscarriage.

holdings.text: The signed statements of Joginder Singh and Balbir Singh had been annexed to the inquest report... looked like a device adopted to get round the bar of Section 162 Criminal Procedure Code. It also shows that the police was not quite confident about the reliability of the two alleged eye witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the appellant drew our attention to the fact that the signed statements of Joginder Singh and Balbir Singh had been annexed to the inquest report and proved by the prosecution. It is rightly pointed out that this looked like a device adopted to get round the bar of Section 162 Criminal Procedure Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Annexing signed statements circumvents s.162 bar on prior statements, indicates police doubt in eyewitness reliability.

holdings.text: The F.I.R. was lodged much later than shown at 9.55 p.m., drafted after Joginder Singh convinced police of appellant's guilt.

anchor.surface_text: although his name is mentioned in the F.I.R. which was shown as lodged at Police Station, Civil Lines, Patiala, on 22-2- 1970, as early as 9.55 p.m. We have examined a carbon copy of the very neatly written I.R. at Police Station, Civil Lines Patiala, in which the time of the occurrence is given as 9 p.m.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Neat detailed FIR unlikely in minutes; no dispatch time to magistrate; inconsistencies in timing.

holdings.text: The hand-writing on the letter Ex. X tallied with the admitted hand-writing of Balbir Singh, P.W.2... We see no reason to discard the evidence of the hand-writing expert.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant documents were, however, sent to and examined by Shanti Sarup Jain, D.W.1, a handwriting expert who had given a detailed report coming to the conclusion that the hand- writing on the letter Ex. X tallied with the admitted hand-writing of Balbir Singh, P.W.2.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Expert report detailed; court examined writings; High Court misread by saying letter not put to witness.

holdings.text: It was not possible to connect the cartridges with the gun... gun not sent for fingerprints... chick not taken into possession.

anchor.surface_text: The ballistic expert, called in as a defence witness, was not even questioned on the point, Here, we may refer to the evidence of Ballistic expert Shri K. Sinha, D-W. 10. Assistant Director of the Forensic Science Laboratory, who was not produced by the prosecution probably because he had made a report showing that it was not possible to connect the cartridges with the gun

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution failed to produce ballistic expert linking gun/cartridges, no fingerprints examined, chick not seized; best evidence withheld.

holdings.text: Conduct of the accused such as hiding after the offence, by itself, does not conclude matters.

anchor.surface_text: Considerable emphasis has been laid by learned Counsel for the State on the fact that the appellant was not traceable or was absconding until he surrendered in a Magistrates court nearly a year after the murder... Reliance was placed by the appellants Counsel on Prakash Mahadeo Godse v. State of Maharashtra, to contend that conduct of the accused such as hiding after the offence, by itself, does not conclude matters.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absconding raises suspicion only, insufficient without proof; follows precedent Prakash Mahadeo Godse.

holdings.text: This evidence does not appear to us to be strong enough to establish that the appellant was actually at Delhi at the time of the murder.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had given some evidence to support his plea that he was actually at Delhi staying at the Sarai of Gurdwara Sis Ganj on 22-2-1970... We do not, however, think that this evidence established that the appellant was actually present at the Sarai during the night on which the murder took place.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Register entry and practice raise presumption but not proof; no direct sighting on murder night.

holdings.text: No need for presumption against prosecution from non-production of witnesses as eyewitnesses unreliable anyway.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the appellant needs the support of any presumption from non-production of any of these witnesses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Primary evidence (eyewitnesses) already crumbled; no additional presumption required.

holdings.text: These injuries were caused when the muzzle of the gun was at a distance of about 6 feet from the body.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. G. S. Gambhir, the Medical Officer, who had performed the postmortem examination, said, after looking at, the injuries of Thakar Singh These injuries were caused when the muzzle of the gun was at a distance of about 6 feet from the body.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Postmortem findings show spread of pellets consistent with 6 ft distance, contradicting close-range entry.

anchor.surface_text: After having been taken through the evidence on record we have come to the conclusion that the superstructure of the prosecution case is based on the testimony of two alleged eye-witnesses whose evidence is not only of an inherently unreliable nature but the artificial and incredible versions of the shooting put forward by them are too unnatural to be accepted.

In any case the super-structure of the prosecution case, based on the testimony of two alleged eye witnesses, having crumbled in the case before us, we find it impossible number to give the appellant the benefit of doubt because of circumstances which
